The second person was born in the great pure family of Brahmins, named Upagupta, a youth who was well-versed in all treatises.

At that time, Upagupta had a wife named Manavika, who was upright and delightful, pleasing to behold, supreme and wonderful, incomparable in the world. She was loved and respected by Upagupta, and if he did not see her for a moment, his mind would become displeased.
At that time, Manavika, his wife, had some minor matters that she was dissatisfied with, and so she stopped speaking to Upagupta.
At that time, Upagupta was troubled and distressed, and thought like this:
Today my wife Manavika does not speak to me, and her voice is cut off like this.
Later, when Manavika, his wife, passed the four months of summer and arrived at the autumn season, she said to the young man Upagupta:
Excellent, holy son!
You can now go to the market and buy the best ointments, incense powders, and various flowers.
Why is it so?
The four months of autumn have now arrived, and all the people are enjoying the five desires together. We too must adorn our bodies and enjoy the five desires.
At that time, the young man Upagupta, having heard these words, was overjoyed, and his body was filled with delight, unable to contain himself. He thought like this:
Now, why has my wife Manavika suddenly spoken to me?

At that time, Upagupta had a gold coin that he had lent to someone else in another village. He set out from his home at noon, when the sun was scorching the earth and the ground was glowing red like a rooster, and went to that village to collect the money.
On the road, his desire became overwhelming, and he began to sing a lustful song.
At that time, he was not far from the palace of King Brahmadatta.

King Brahmadatta was on a rooftop, enjoying the cool breeze. During the day, he would take a nap. When he woke up from his nap, he suddenly heard that person's lustful song filled with desire for the five sense objects.
When the king heard it, he immediately aroused his own desire. There is a verse that goes:
Either due to habitual tendencies from the past, or because the situation stirs the emotions,
This is caused by attachment to the desire for form and love, like a lotus flower growing in water.
At that time, Brahmadatta heard that lewd singing and suddenly became startled and suspicious:
Who is this?
At the height of the midday heat, with a mind attached to desire, singing lewd songs?
Having had this thought, he saw from the window that Upagupta, at midday, when the earth was scorching hot, was singing as he walked on the road. He then called a minister and ordered him, saying:
You should quickly go and seize that singer and bring him to me.
That minister, having heard the order, then said to the king:
I dare not disobey the order.
He then went to his side, seized Upagupta, and said to him:
You young man!
Come, come! The king now summons you.
At that time, Upagupta was terrified, his body hair stood on end, and he was dispirited and unhappy, thinking like this:
Now who knows that I have some offense against Brahmadatta?
causing me to be sorrowful.
At that time, the great minister took Upagupta to King Brahmadatta. When the king saw him, he gave rise to a loving mind. Having given rise to a loving mind, he spoke a verse to that person, saying:
The midday sun is blazing hot, the earth is red like a red-crested cock,
You now indulge in lustful singing, why are you not distressed by this?
The sunlight shines everywhere, blazing hot, the ground melts with sand, even hotter,
You now indulge in lustful singing, why are you not distressed by this?
At that time, the young man Upagupta replied to King Brahmadatta with a verse, saying:
Your Majesty is not distressed now, what has the sun in the sky to do with it?
Only seeking profit and loss, this is the most distressing of all distresses.
This is the least of the afflictions.ğŸ”½Engaging in various kinds of work,

At that time, King Brahmadatta asked the young man Upagupta:

At that time, Upagupta explained the matter to King Brahmadatta.
Then, King Brahmadatta again told the young man Upagupta:
'Young man!
Stop, stop! Do not go!
I will now give you two coins (Indian gold coins).'

At that time, Upagupta received the coins from Brahmadatta and again said to King Brahmadatta:

Although I have received two coins from the great king, I now ask the king for another coin, making three in total. I will go to the village and take one coin myself, adding up to four coins. I can then share them with Manavika to enjoy the pleasures of the five senses during the autumn festival.'
King Brahmadatta then told the young man Upagupta:
'Stop, do not go!

For this reason, I will then be able to enjoy the five desires together with Manavika.
At that time, Brahmadatta again said to him:

' Having thought this, when UpÄka was about to take his sword, he had another thought:

Then King Brahmadatta again said to UpÄli:
'Do as you wish.'

'Since Upagupta has given up such a position as half a king of a country and has gone forth, now King Brahmadatta admires him;

'Great King:

'Upagupta!
Whose side do you wish to go forth to now?
Upagupta said:
Great King!
I wish to go to Upagupta's side to go forth.

Upagupta!
